contentrichtext.text: {{redirect|Icepick|the climbing tool|Ice axe|the hardcore punk band|Icepick (band)|the fictional character|Icepick (Transformers)}} {{more footnotes|date=December 2011}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2011}} [[File:ICEPICK2.jpg|thumb|A standard ice pick]] An '''ice pick''' is a tool used to break up, pick at, or chip at [[ice]]. It resembles a [[scratch awl]], but is designed for picking at ice rather than wood. Before the invention of modern [[refrigerators]], ice picks were a ubiquitous household tool used for separating and shaping the blocks of ice used in [[ice box]]es. Outside the USA, the term ''ice pick'' also commonly refers to a mountaineers' tool known in the USA as an [[ice axe]].<ref>[http://oxforddictionaries.com/view/entry/m_en_gb0397520 Oxford Dictionaries â€“ Ice pick]</ref> ==Other uses== Like most other tools, ice picks have been used for more than their intended use. For example, [[mafia]] [[hitman]] [[Abe Reles|Abe "Kid Twist" Reles]] used an ice pick as his [[weapon]] of choice. Fellow [[Murder, Inc.]] hitman [[Harry Strauss|Harry "Pittsburgh Phil" Strauss]] also employed an ice pick as a weapon. On the show ''[[Deadliest Warrior]]'', the ice pick is featured as a "Mafia weapon" and shown to be capable of piercing through bone easily. In the 1992 movie ''[[Basic Instinct]]'', multiple characters are stabbed with ice picks. A lead female character in Linwood Barclay's 2012 thriller "Trust Your Eyes" uses an ice pick to kill people. [[Neurologist]] [[Walter Freeman (neurologist)|Walter Freeman]] used medical instruments called [[leucotome]]s, and later [[orbitoclast]]s, both of which were essentially ice picks, to perform transorbital [[lobotomy|lobotomies]]. This operation was informally called "ice pick lobotomy": the leucotome was hammered into the patient's brain with a rubber [[mallet]] via the eye's [[tear duct]]. The murder weapon used in the assassination of [[Leon Trotsky]] was a mountaineering ice pick which in American English speaking countries is called an [[ice axe]].<ref>Conquest, Robert. ''The Great Terror: A Reassessment''. Oxford University Press, 1991, ISBN 0-19-507132-8, p. 418.</ref> ==References== {{Commonscat|Ice picks}} <references /> [[Category:Mechanical hand tools]] [[Category:Water ice]]
